rev.comment: /* 28 January â Friday of Anger */ added the arabic name

Line 130: Line 130:
[[File:Al jazeera 2011 egypt protests.ogv|thumb|right|An [[Al Jazeera English]] report on the protests]]
[[File:Al jazeera 2011 egypt protests.ogv|thumb|right|An [[Al Jazeera English]] report on the protests]]
{{wikinews|Egypt anti-government protests continue, internet shut down}}
{{wikinews|Egypt anti-government protests continue, internet shut down}}
â
Thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday 28 January, dubbed âthe Friday of Angerâ.<ref name="Friday of Anger">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/be97d4a8-2b0b-11e0-a65f-00144feab49a.html#axzz1CMDTT7Ao|title=Pent-up anger bursts on to Cairo streets|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref> {{Citation needed (lead)}}<ref>http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/01/awaiting-the-friday-of-anger.html</ref> Shortly before 1:00 am local time, hours ahead of the expected massive anti-government protests, the Egyptian government shut down internet service, although some people were still able to communicate using alternative means.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh protests erupt in Egypt - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arabist.net/blog/2011/1/28/urgent-egypt-has-shut-off-the-internet.html |title=URGENT: Egypt has shut off the internet |publisher=Arabist |last=El Amrani |first=Issandr |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/hack/2011/01/egypt-tor-use-skyrocketing-as.php |title=Egypt: Tor Use Skyrocketing as Users Route-Around Internet Blocks |publisher=Read Write Web |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> Text messaging and mobile phone services also appeared to be blocked.<ref>{{cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&iref=BN1 |title=Violent clashes erupt during protests in Egypt |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> All mobile operators in Egypt have been instructed to suspend services in selected areas. Under Egyptian legislation the authorities have the right to issue such an order and the operators are obliged to comply.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/press.html |title=Press |publisher=Vodafone |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
+
Thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday 28 January, dubbed '''The Friday of Anger''' ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}}.<ref name="Friday of Anger">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/be97d4a8-2b0b-11e0-a65f-00144feab49a.html#axzz1CMDTT7Ao|title=Pent-up anger bursts on to Cairo streets|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref> {{Citation needed (lead)}}<ref>http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/01/awaiting-the-friday-of-anger.html</ref> Shortly before 1:00 am local time, hours ahead of the expected massive anti-government protests, the Egyptian government shut down internet service, although some people were still able to communicate using alternative means.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh protests erupt in Egypt - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arabist.net/blog/2011/1/28/urgent-egypt-has-shut-off-the-internet.html |title=URGENT: Egypt has shut off the internet |publisher=Arabist |last=El Amrani |first=Issandr |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/hack/2011/01/egypt-tor-use-skyrocketing-as.php |title=Egypt: Tor Use Skyrocketing as Users Route-Around Internet Blocks |publisher=Read Write Web |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> Text messaging and mobile phone services also appeared to be blocked.<ref>{{cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&iref=BN1 |title=Violent clashes erupt during protests in Egypt |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> All mobile operators in Egypt have been instructed to suspend services in selected areas. Under Egyptian legislation the authorities have the right to issue such an order and the operators are obliged to comply.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/press.html |title=Press |publisher=Vodafone |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
Shortly after [[Friday prayers]], tens of thousands of Egyptians started protesting, and within hours the number rose to the hundreds of thousands. Potential [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|presidential candidate]] [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] returned to Cairo and said that he planned to join the protesters.<ref name="ElBaradei to join Egypt protest">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/ElBaradei-to-join-Egypt-protest-20110127|title=ElBaradei to join Egypt protest|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|publisher=news24}}</ref><ref name="Mohamed ElBaradei: There's no going back">{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/elbaradei-return-cairo-egypt|title=Mohamed ElBaradei: There's no going back|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> ElBaradei has been leading the protests in Giza. On 28 January ElBaradei was arrested at an anti-government rally<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4020436,00.html |title=Report: ElBaradei arrested in Egypt |publisher=Al ynetnews |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> and placed under house arrest.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/28/clashes-erupt-in-cairo-elbaradei-told-to-stay-put-cnn-camera-confiscated/ | title=Unrest in Egypt: Mubarak expected to speak; curfew imposed in major cities | accessdate=2011-01-28 | publisher=CNN}}</ref>. ElBaradei told Al Jazeera the next day that he was unaware of his house arrest. <ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112974149942894.html | title=Protesters back on Egypt streets | accessdate=2011-01-29 | publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref>
Shortly after [[Friday prayers]], tens of thousands of Egyptians started protesting, and within hours the number rose to the hundreds of thousands. Potential [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|presidential candidate]] [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] returned to Cairo and said that he planned to join the protesters.<ref name="ElBaradei to join Egypt protest">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/ElBaradei-to-join-Egypt-protest-20110127|title=ElBaradei to join Egypt protest|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|publisher=news24}}</ref><ref name="Mohamed ElBaradei: There's no going back">{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/elbaradei-return-cairo-egypt|title=Mohamed ElBaradei: There's no going back|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> ElBaradei has been leading the protests in Giza. On 28 January ElBaradei was arrested at an anti-government rally<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4020436,00.html |title=Report: ElBaradei arrested in Egypt |publisher=Al ynetnews |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> and placed under house arrest.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/28/clashes-erupt-in-cairo-elbaradei-told-to-stay-put-cnn-camera-confiscated/ | title=Unrest in Egypt: Mubarak expected to speak; curfew imposed in major cities | accessdate=2011-01-28 | publisher=CNN}}</ref>. ElBaradei told Al Jazeera the next day that he was unaware of his house arrest. <ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112974149942894.html | title=Protesters back on Egypt streets | accessdate=2011-01-29 | publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref>
